moves.1. e4: I started with an open mind and was vaguely thinking about a four move checkmate.
moves.1... e5: He opened with a common defense to a pawn at e4.
moves.2. Bc4: I moved out my bishop, continuing my planned attack.
moves.2... Nf6: He moved out his knight, also a common defense, but this time realizing my intentions.
moves.3. d3: I moved out a pawn preparing to threaten the knight with my queen-side bishop.
moves.3... Bc5: He moved out his king-side bishop in order to gain a vantage point, and control part of the middle.
moves.4. Qf3: I developed my queen to threaten the knight, however, not planning to attack.
moves.4... c6: He moved out a pawn to open his queen on the left side.
moves.5. Bg5: I moved my black bishop to threaten an attack.
moves.5... h6: He moved out his pawn, forcing a decision, either retreat or attack and sacrifice.
moves.6... Qxf6: He decides to attack with queen, knowing I wouldn't attack.
moves.7. Qxf6: I moved this way, not my best, In order to stay unpredictable and not be too easy to notice.
moves.7... gxf6: He obviously took the queen, after a few seconds though.
moves.8. Nh3: I moved out my knight, rethinking my plan.
moves.8... d6: He opened up his bishop, to threaten
moves.9. f4: I moved out my pawn to open up a space for my knights next move.
moves.9... exf4: He decided it would also be in his best interest to attack that pawn, this small mistake, allowed me to learn what he prioritized.
moves.10. Nxf4: I took the pawn, planning the next move out.
moves.10... Be6: He threatened my remaining bishop with his.
moves.11. Bxe6: I took his bishop with mine, not the knight, because I was planning something else...I'm not a very good planner.
moves.11... fxe6: He killed my bishop with his pawn, accepting the sacrifice.
moves.12. Nc3: Noticing his flat line, I decided to attempt a jump over the line.
moves.12... Bb4: He moved his final bishop, knowing I was stuck in position.
moves.13. a3: I, like him previously, decided to make him choose something.
moves.13... Bxc3+: He took my knight for the sacrifice.
moves.14. bxc3: I continued the motion by knocking his piece off the board.
moves.14... e5: He threatened my knight with a pawn, adding depth to his front lines again.
moves.15. Ng6: In a slightly blind attempt to attack the king...I was a bit off, eh?
moves.15... Rg8: Anyway, he saw the...er, deliberate threat on his rook and set course for safety.
moves.16. Nh4: I found safety from his attack and dropped back.
moves.16... Rg4: He was apparently bloodthirsty though, because he continued on the trail of my final surviving livestock.
moves.17. Rb1: I decided to "ignore" the dying screams and setup for yet another offensive threat.
moves.17... Rxh4: He took the knight and destroyed his chance of defense.
moves.18. Rxb7: I moved to threaten his knight but, more importantly, try to kill off the king.
moves.18... Rg4: His coloured piece tried to recover from taking the knight, but It was already too late.
moves.19. Rf1: I moved my next rook out for the attack.
moves.19... Rf4: He obviously saw this and stopped it at once, planning a sacrifice.
moves.20. Rg1: In no mood for dying, I avoided it.
moves.20... Rg4: He was yet again thirsty for the blood of my pieces, but this time, it was for stacked bricks.
moves.21. h3: I threatened him with out risking sacrifice.
moves.21... Rg8: He retreated knowing no place, and secretly setting for counter attack.
moves.22. Rf1: I moved back, for my original plan- well actually my 3rd plan.
moves.22... Na6: He opened up his rook, after 22 long moves.
moves.23. Rxf6: I moved out my rook to continue on the plan.
moves.23... Nc5: He threatened an attack, to cover the trail of his hidden rook.
moves.24. Rbf7: I avoided his attempt and still continued attack.
moves.25... Kd7: He moved out of the way, as his final resort.
moves.26. Rxa8: I took his rook swiftly after pinning him.
moves.26... Rxc2: He attacked a pawn, with shrouded intentions.
moves.27. Raf8: I recovered back to my original position.
moves.27... Nxd3+: His thoughts clear to me now as he put me in check.
moves.28. Kd1: I moved to threaten his piece.
moves.28... Rc1+: He avoided threat and checked me again.
moves.29. Kd2: I forked his knight and rook.
moves.29... Kc7: He saved his rook, already protected, and moved away from my next attack.
moves.30. Kxd3: I took his helpless knight and continued.
moves.31. Kc4: I moved out adding to my plan.
moves.31... d5+: He was persistent and forced a final +.
moves.32. Kc5: I blocked his king, closing in on him.
moves.32... dxe4: He tried to make a pawn to my end, in a futile defense.
moves.33. Rf6f7+: I checked him, in what I thought was mate, forgetting about his rook.
moves.33... Rd7: He basically dug his own grave.
moves.34. h4: I avoided the kill, knowing I was next.
moves.34... Rxf7: He took my rook, but this time, I was ready.
moves.35... Kc8: He avoided in the only way he could.
moves.36. Kxc6: I closed down on him, not putting him in check however.
moves.36... e3: He tried reviving his queen again. Failing.
moves.37. Rf8#: 'Mate. My king acting as a wall of pawns, had fully migrated. Good game to the one who chose not to be named. Hope you liked it. Please tune in next time for #2. Thanks for reading.
